title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, 30 june [1869]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 30 June [1869]
text: 30 June1869June 30June 30My dear walterWalteri will only write a very few lines this time i receevedreceived your letter to day wensdayWednesdayi withewith the contents all safe and i have been down to the post office and got the order changed it come good as we had got rather run ashore but walterWalter dear i had enoughfenough to get along i dontdon't know how i should get on without you waltWalt but i suppose there would be some way they dontdon't think that i have no way but what is given to me i suppose georgeGeorge thinks he finds me a house for his part well its good and i am thankfullthankful as we have never or not late years been fixed so nicely but at the same time we must have something else i have stood the hot weather pretty well it has been very warm indeed here and every where i suppose) i have had my face swelled and red and pricked so i didentdidn't know what to doodo it is bloated some yet but dontdon't feel such a heat as i have i think it must be the heat because i haventhaven't been out in the sun so its not that) i have had a letter from jeffyJeffy and one from mattyMatty since i last wrote to you they both come emtyempty but i suppose they have ways for all they have dontdon't think i suppose mattyMatty says she is certainly coming on here this fall they have got intimately acquainted with a railroad agent so they think they can come freegeorgeGeorge is away yet has been gone longer this time than any time yet i expect he will be home on saturdaySaturday O waltWalt the papers came all safe i shall read them to night i am glad to get a paper i dontdon't take any when georgeGeorge is gone only the little morning union a penypenny paper its better than none i beleivebelieve i wontwon't write any more i feel so tired so good by Waltlove to all the folks Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, 30 June [1869]
